channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Sustainability Draft: German Brewers Warn Against Fracking
item.description: German brewers are worried that shale gas removal could end up contaminating the water they use to make the national drink. They have sent an open letter to six government ministers to call for a moratorium on fracking.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE

item.title: Delhi Journal: Cow Thefts on the Rise in India
item.description: With meat eating on the rise in India, cows — considered sacred in Hinduism — are being stolen off the street by cattle rustlers and sold to illegal slaughterhouses.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Enrico Fabian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taking a break at Shri Mataji Gaushala, a shelter in Uttar Pradesh, India, for thousands of cattle. The eating of beef is becoming more common in India.

item.title: Computers Piecing Together Jigsaw of Jewish Lore
item.description: The idea is to help reassemble more than 100,000 document fragments collected across 1,000 years that reveal details of Jewish life along the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roni Shweka and his father, Yaacov Shweka, with a computerized fragment of a document found in the Ben Ezra synagogue in Cairo.

item.title: Obama’s Strategy Shows Misunderstanding of Terrorist Threat, Republicans Say
item.description: Lawmakers reacted to the president’s plan to narrow the war on terrorism.
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

item.title: Thousands March in France Against Gay Marriage
item.description: The march ocurred as a recent poll showed many French were losing patience with protests against the “marriage for all” law that passed on May 18.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Protesters marched on Sunday during a demonstration against same-sex marriage in Paris.

item.title: Boston Marathon Winner Will Donate Medal
item.description: The champion Ethiopian runner Lelisa Desisa said his “joy turned to sorrow” after the April 15 bombing, and he dedicated his victory to the victims.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Lelisa Desisa with United States Secretary of State John Kerry at the American Embassy in Ethiopia

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: James Gray Makes His Way on the Cannes Star Circuit
item.description: For stars, protocol at Cannes means official dinners, endless photographs, dozens of interviews and a walk down the red carpet.
item.dc:creator: By MANOHLA DARGIS
item.media:description: From left, James Gray, Marion Cotillard and Jeremy Renner.

item.title: Israeli Electric Car Company Files for Liquidation
item.description: Better Place failed to attract many customers to its battery-swapping service plan, and its largest shareholder decided against further investment.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: American Al Jazeera Channel Shifs Focus to U.S. News
item.description: To counter skepticism about its Al Jazeera America cable channel, the Qatar-based network is building a sizable news organization to cover the United States.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN STELTER

item.title: The Caucus: Wind Down the War on Terrorism? Republicans Say No
item.description: Republican lawmakers assailed President Obama’s vision for winding down the war on terrorism, using talk show appearances to accuse him of misunderstanding the terror threat in a way that will embolden unfriendly nations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

item.title: Rockets Strike Hezbollah’s Beirut Stronghold
item.description: Four were wounded in a mysterious strike on Beirut suburbs controlled by the militant group Hezbollah that seems linked to the militant group’s growing role in the Syrian war next door.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Two wounded men were treated on Sunday by their friends after two rockets hit their houses in Beirut.

item.title: Letter From Washington: Doing More for U.S. Veterans
item.description: Ahead of the Memorial Day holiday, some veterans' advocates are calling on the White House to address issues like the large backlog on processing benefits claims of those who once served.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALBERT R. HUNT | BLOOMBERG VIEW

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 25
item.description: Museums restore dignity of dead; C.I.A.’s new strategy; rape concerns in Rio de Janiero; Brigham Young’s film talent, and antitrust scrutiny for Google.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Schnalke, director of the Museum of Medical History in Berlin, helped write new guidelines on how to handle human remains like these bones displayed at his institution.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: America’s Profligate Ways With Water
item.description: More than a decade ago, scientists warned that U.S. groundwater levels were dropping at alarming rates. That caused little talk and less action. Now the science is plain.
item.dc:creator: By MORT ROSENBLUM

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Failing to Convince Assad
item.description: The goal of John Kerry’s meetings with his Arab and European counterparts was to eventually change Bashar al-Assad’s calculus. It is far from clear how that will happen.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID ROHDE
item.media:description: Diplomats pose for a group photo in Amman on May 22. Pictured (front L-R) Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu of Turkey, Foreign Minister Prince Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, Prime Minister Sheik Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani of Qatar, Foreign Minister Nasser Judeh of Jordan, Secretary of State John Kerry, Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah Bin Zayed al-Nahyan of the United Arab Emirates, Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle of Germany, (rear L-R) Foreign Minister Khalid bin Mohamed Al-Attiyah of Qatar, Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius of France, Foreign Secretary William Hague of Britain, Foreign Minister Mohamed Kamel Amr of Egypt and Foreign Minister Emma Bonino of Italy.

item.title: Peres Says Israel Must Overcome Skepticism About Peace
item.description: At a conference in Jordan, President Shimon Peres of Israel said there was an urgent need for peace with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Rockets Hit Hezbollah Stronghold in Lebanon
item.description: Rockets slammed Sunday into two southern Beirut neighborhoods that are strongholds of Lebanon’s Hezbollah group, wounding four people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Maoist Attack Kills Dozens in India
item.description: At least 27 people, including three leaders of the nationally dominant Indian National Congress Party, were killed when Maoist guerrillas ambushed a convoy in Chhattisgarh.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR

item.title: In Afghan Transition, U.S. Forces Take a Step Back
item.description: As the United States military moves into a support role in Afghanistan, a week spent with a brigade accompanying Afghan forces offered a direct look at the evolving training mission, for better or for worse.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Third Brigade Combat Team of the 101st Airborne Division has been training Afghanistan’s security forces in an effort to help them become self-sufficient.

item.title: U.S. Shift Poses Risk to Pakistan
item.description: An American withdrawal from Afghanistan and the curtailment of the drone campaign could plunge Pakistan’s hotbed tribal areas into further chaos.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistanis in Multan, in Punjab Province, in January denounced American drone strikes.

item.title: Kerry Presses Nigeria on Human Rights
item.description: A visit to Africa by Secretary of State John Kerry comes as amid several developments on the continent, but Syria was still on his agenda.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke on Saturday in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

item.title: Three Arrested in Soldier’s Killing in Britain
item.description: The police arrested three men in their 20s in an areas of southeast London not far from the site of a fatal attack on an off-duty soldier on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Japanese Lab Workers Exposed to Radiation
item.description: While the leak was small, it received intensive coverage in Japan’s news media, a reflection of the country’s anxiety over nuclear safety.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: A Region in Myanmar Limits Births of Muslims
item.description: The unusual order makes Myanmar perhaps the only country in the world to impose such a restriction on a religious group.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Yemen Makes Strides in Transition to Democracy
item.description: For more than two months, a cross section of Yemen’s population has gathered, trying to hammer out the shape a future government will take.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Most detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, are Yemeni, like this woman’s son. President Obama last week lifted a moratorium on repatriating some of the inmates.
